question: What are the 4 main components of an Android application?
correctAnswer: Activity, Service, Content Provider, Broadcast Receiver
incorrectAnswers: Fragment, Intent Service, Content Loader, Receiver
Manifest, Gradle Scripts, Res Folder, Java Folder
WorkManager, Room, Coroutines, Navigation

question: What is Context?
correctAnswer: The current state of the application
incorrectAnswers: Understand how the user interacts with our app
The location in memory of the app on the device
Where the user is interacting in our app

question: What is Context used for?
correctAnswer: Get information regarding the activity and application
incorrectAnswers: Understand how the user interacts with our app
The location in memory of the app on the device
Relates to the .xml files

question: What is an Activity
correctAnswer: A single screen that the user can interact with
incorrectAnswers: Handles long running operation without user interaction
Allows the application to response to Android intents
Manages access to a central repository of data

question: What is a Service
correctAnswer: Handles long running operation without user interaction
incorrectAnswers: A single screen that the user can interact with
Allows the application to response to Android intents
Manages access to a central repository of data

question: What is a Broadcast Receiver
correctAnswer: Allows the application to response to Android intents
incorrectAnswers: A single screen that the user can interact with
Handles long running operation without user interaction
Manages access to a central repository of data

question: What is a Content Provider
correctAnswer: Manages access to a central repository of data
incorrectAnswers: A single screen that the user can interact with
Handles long running operation without user interaction
Allows the application to response to Android intents

question: What is the lifecycle of an Activity?
correctAnswer: onCreate, onStart, onResume, onPause, onStop, onDestroy
incorrectAnswers: onAttach, onCreateView, onViewCreated, onDestroy, onDetach
startService, bindService, unbindService, stopService
startActivity, onContinue, onBreak, endActivity

question: What is the use of Bundle?
correctAnswer: Used to pass data between Activities or Fragments
incorrectAnswers: Serializes our custom objects
To group our android components
Wraps our intents

question: What is AIDL?
correctAnswer: Android Interface Definition Language
incorrectAnswers: All In Defined Logs
Also Interactable Don't Lie
Android Interaction Design Lingo

question: What data types are supported by AIDL?
correctAnswer: String, List, Map, CharSequence and Java primitives
incorrectAnswers: Only Java primitives
Custom types defined in the manifest
Android specific types

question: What is the Android Manifest?
correctAnswer: Information about the application Android needs to know about
incorrectAnswers: Where our Java/Kotlin code is written
Information about our min/target SDK
Android specific types

question: What is an intent
correctAnswer: A messaging object used to request an action from other components
incorrectAnswers: An object only used to start other activities
Information about the application the Android needs to know about
Handles long running operation without user interaction

question: Explicit Intents are used for...
correctAnswer: Invoking an android component
incorrectAnswers: Invoking various system components based on type
Getting information regarding the activity
A hard coded message for other applications

question: Implicit Intents are used for...
correctAnswer: Invoking various system components based on type
incorrectAnswers: Invoking an android component
Getting information regarding the activity
A hard coded message for other applications

question: What is an ANR?
correctAnswer: Application Not Responding
incorrectAnswers: App Not Ready
Application No Retry
Always Never Run

question: An ANR can be caused by...
correctAnswer: No response to an input event after 5 seconds
incorrectAnswers: Android not recognizing your app
Your Kotlin code not matching Java code
Components not being specified in the manifest

question: What are the activity launch modes?
correctAnswer: standard, singleTop, singleTask, singleInstance
incorrectAnswers: default, singleton, module, viewModel
onCreate, onStart, onResume, onPause, onStop, onDestroy
FrameLayout, ConstraintLayout, LinearLayout, RelativeLayout

question: What is the compileSDK?
correctAnswer: The version of API the application is compiled against
incorrectAnswers: The API level of the Android device where the app expects to run
The minimum API level where the application is able to run
Tells the compiler which code language to use

question: What is the targetSDK?
correctAnswer: The API level of the Android device where the app expects to run
incorrectAnswers: The version of API the application is compiled against
The minimum API level where the application is able to run
Tells the SDK which device type it should target

question: What is the minSDK?
correctAnswer: The minimum API level where the application is able to run
incorrectAnswers: The version of API the application is compiled against
The API level of the Android device where the app expects to run
Tells the SDK how much code is needed to begin the application

question: What does ProGuard do for our app?
correctAnswer: Shrinks, obfuscates and optimizes our code
incorrectAnswers: Bundles our generated classes
The system that sends notifies us about warnings and errors in our IDE
We do not have ProGuard in Android

question: What is not an example of a normal permission?
correctAnswer: SEND_SMS
incorrectAnswers: INTERNET
SET_ALARM
BLUETOOTH

question: What is not an example of a dangerous permission?
correctAnswer: ACCESS_NOTIFICATION_POLICY
incorrectAnswers: RECORD_AUDIO
SEND_SMS
ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION

question: What is a dangerous permission?
correctAnswer: A permission that can affect the user's privacy
incorrectAnswers: A permission that can crash the app is not handled
A permission that leaves the app vulnerable to being hacked
A permission that can overheat the device
